awd_titl_txt: Decadal changes in ventilation of the abyssal Southwest Pacific ocean from repeated CFC and new SF6 measurements
awd_abstract_narration:
Oceanic distributions of anthropogenic trace gases provide critical measures of how quickly the ocean interacts with the atmosphere, and its anthropogenic changes, that are difficult to obtain otherwise. Tracer data have been used by scientists to identify large-scale patterns and rates of variability in ventilation, and are critical for validation of climate models. This project will result in high-quality, full water column, tracer data sets which will be available to the broader community via the internet. In addition, the study will train a graduate student in the analytical methods, interpretation, and modeling of these data.

The US Repeat Hydrography program includes 6 meridional sections that cross the Antarctic Circumpolar Current and extend into Antarctic waters. The chlorofluorocarbon/sulfur hexafluoride measurements are classified as Level 1 data - of the highest priority - and have been funded through both the National Science Foundation and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration on all of these sections. The zonal spacing between these sections ranges from 25 to 120 degrees of longitude, with the largest gap between 90°E and 150°W. There are two meridional sections in this region that are carried out by the Australians - SR3 along 140°E between Tasmania and Antarctica, and P15S along 170°W between 70°S and the equator. While the Australians carry out most of the Level 1 measurements, they do not have a sea-going chlorofluorocarbon laboratory. To fill this gap in 2001 and 2008/2009, the University of Washington and National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration-Pacific Marine Environmental Laboratory with support from the National Science Foundation and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, collaborated with the Australians to make chlorofluorocarbon measurements on both sections. This proposed research will continue the collaboration, measuring chlorofluorocarbons/ sulfur hexafluoride along P15S (April - June 2016) and SR3 (December 2016 - January 2017). This project will collect the data and interpret tracer distributions in context of changes to the ventilation of deep and bottom waters.

por.por_cntn:
Oceanic distributions of the anthropogenic trace gases, chlorofluorocarbons-11 and-12  or CFC-11 and CFC-12, plus SF6, have provided a large amount of information on the pathways and time-scales for waters to move from the surface mixed layer into the interior ocean.  The 1990s global survey of the CFC distributions during the World Ocean Circulation Experiment provided a blurred snapshot of the oceanic uptake of these compounds into the thermoclines of the subtropical gyres, and into intermediate, deep, and abyssal waters.  These tracers provide critical measures of how quickly the ocean interacts with the atmosphere, and its anthropogenic changes, that are difficult to obtain otherwise.  The measurements of these tracers along two of these repeat hydrography sections - P15S, nominally at 170 W and SR03, nominally along 140 E - were carried out from the Australian R.V. Investigator in 2016 and 2018 respectively. The tracers continued to increase within the ocean interior along both sections. The CFCs and SF6 distributions are consistent with little change in the densities of the bottom waters formed along the Adelie Land continental shelf, and are consistant with a reduction in the amount of bottom water being formed (see Figs 1 and 2)

 The concentrations measured in the multiple crossings of the deep western boundary current of the southwestern Pacific along P15S enable us to further constrain the transport.  Since this is the primary pathway for anthropogenic signals (e.g. heat, CO2) to the deep North Pacific, these constraints are important for understanding the long-term storage of these signals.

    We also measured the seawater  concentrations of nitrous oxide on both of these voyages. These are the first high spatial resolution sections in this region. The N2O data have already contributed to an effort to constrain the fluxes of N2O from the ocean to the atmosphere. 

   A graduate student was involved in the interpretation of changes in the properties of the DWBC as part of her M.S. degree.  In addition, a researcher from JISAO (now CICOSE) was trained as the lead tracer analyst during the P15S re-occupation, and now assumes that role for the NOAA contribution to GO-SHIP


Last Modified: 01/04/2022
Modified by: Mark J Warner

por.por_txt_cntn:
Oceanic distributions of the anthropogenic trace gases, chlorofluorocarbons-11 and-12  or CFC-11 and CFC-12, plus SF6, have provided a large amount of information on the pathways and time-scales for waters to move from the surface mixed layer into the interior ocean.  The 1990s global survey of the CFC distributions during the World Ocean Circulation Experiment provided a blurred snapshot of the oceanic uptake of these compounds into the thermoclines of the subtropical gyres, and into intermediate, deep, and abyssal waters.  These tracers provide critical measures of how quickly the ocean interacts with the atmosphere, and its anthropogenic changes, that are difficult to obtain otherwise.  The measurements of these tracers along two of these repeat hydrography sections - P15S, nominally at 170 W and SR03, nominally along 140 E - were carried out from the Australian R.V. Investigator in 2016 and 2018 respectively. The tracers continued to increase within the ocean interior along both sections. The CFCs and SF6 distributions are consistent with little change in the densities of the bottom waters formed along the Adelie Land continental shelf, and are consistant with a reduction in the amount of bottom water being formed (see Figs 1 and 2)

 The concentrations measured in the multiple crossings of the deep western boundary current of the southwestern Pacific along P15S enable us to further constrain the transport.  Since this is the primary pathway for anthropogenic signals (e.g. heat, CO2) to the deep North Pacific, these constraints are important for understanding the long-term storage of these signals.

    We also measured the seawater  concentrations of nitrous oxide on both of these voyages. These are the first high spatial resolution sections in this region. The N2O data have already contributed to an effort to constrain the fluxes of N2O from the ocean to the atmosphere. 

   A graduate student was involved in the interpretation of changes in the properties of the DWBC as part of her M.S. degree.  In addition, a researcher from JISAO (now CICOSE) was trained as the lead tracer analyst during the P15S re-occupation, and now assumes that role for the NOAA contribution to GO-SHIP
